Good intro to the importance of bees. Two points could have been given more emphasis:

i) honey bees are the minority of bees on the planet, and in fact are entirely introduced (and at best quasi-invasive) in the Americas. Wild bees are incredibly important but often overlooked (as the case here) to the functioning of our ecosystems and even our food production.

ii) bees are inherently valuable. If all the bees die we would lose an inherently important part of our ecosystems. That said, we would lose many of our ecosystems overall as bees pollinate not just food but many of the other plants on our planet.

Please keep making these videos - very enjoyable to watch with lots of solid, accessible (but never dumbed down) information.

Your video is wrong from the start. Bees are rarely the primary pollinators of any plant or tree. Flies are usually the most common pollinator, but ants, wasps, hornets, wild bees, hummingbirds, and dozens of other bugs fulfill that role as well.

Additionally, honeybees are not native to most areas of the world, such as America, so they didn't belong here in the first place. Honeybees also had to he domesticated and bred to become tolerant of colder climates, for example in America primitive, wild honeybees (aka Africanized) won't swarm north of about Arkansas.

If honeybees all died tomorrow, other than honey production, there would be almost no change, and any change that occurred would probably only be noticeable next year until the alternative pollinators filled the bees niche.

People really need to be educated about the fact that bees are not the only pollinators in the world. In fact, yellowjackets do far more pollination, they do not attack when they are foraging, and their stings are not as fatal as bees, but they get a bad rap just for being more defensive of their queens.

I'm a beekeeper. This video is full of misinformation. First; CCD has been a known issue for hundreds of years. The fact that it hit particularly hard in the 1990s isn't what has made it such a big issue. What has is it's coincidental timing with the rise of the environmental movement. It has become one more adopted "cause" in the agenda of the green movement. Along with/because of the attention generated by the environmental movement and political pressure by big agriculture has come the promise of tax funded, rather than in house, bee health R&D. And after all, why would commercial beekeepers be in any hurry to admit CCD has always been a recurring problem when there's free R&D money on the table? Second, setting aside the fact that neonicotinoids have been shown in several studies to have no effect on bees, and not one study has shown otherwise; why would the very farmers who rely on bees for crop pollination, pay to use a product that would kill them. Farmers aren't stupid, nor are the big Chem corporations who live to profit from improving crop yields for those farmers. If it hurts bees, it hurts crops. If it hurts crops, it hurts farmers. If it hurts farmers, they won't buy it. Simple common sense.

I love this channel, but I do have a few questions/remarks about this one. 

First of all, what is known about the contribution of wild, solitary bees and other pollinating species like bumble bees, butterflies and certain birds? 

Second, it's illogical to point out that it would lead to less food to feed to livestock so humans would have less animals to eat... How about just leaving out the animals in this food chain? ;) Less pollination means less plants-based foods for humans. If humans would eat crops themselves instead of first feeding it to livestock, we would save so much food (and water; it would also mean a huge reduction in pollution: watch Cowspiracy; it would also put an end to the horrific practices of animal agriculture in terms of animal welfare).

Third, I don't see a problem in the case of cotton. It is one of the most polluting industries in terms of pesticide use, so having to find alternatives for it should only be applauded right?

Just some food for thought :)

Slight problem with this video.

"Bees" when used in this reference refers almost exclusively to the European Honeybee.  As it's name implies, these bees are from Europe, they are not native to North America or other parts of the world.  If all the "bees" in the world died tomorrow, native pollinators would reclaim their niches and keep right on pollinating native plants.

You are using "bees" when you are referring to all pollinating insects, which also include things like mosquitoes (yes, mosquitoes are pollinators) and the common house fly (the Paw Paw fruit tree is the largest fruit native to North America, it is pollinated by flies, not bees).

Yes, we would be in serious trouble if we lost all pollinating insects on Earth.  No, we would not be in that much trouble if the european honeybee went extinct tomorrow.

And this is coming from a beekeeper with a state licensed apiary.

Just a few points.
-Bees are not the only insect pollinators, or pollinators. Although they're definitely the most significant.
-Only 3 food crops are mentioned here that are self pollinators; there are many more variety of plants, including fruits (eg. oranges) and vegetables (eg. peppers) that are self pollinators.
-We could, technically, develop genetically modified plants that would normally require pollination from a bee to be self pollinated instead. Pre-existing orchards could graft this to pre-existing trees.
-Other industries could replace cotton for the textile industry (hemp?).
-Human labor to pollinate plants
Although it is true we would not go extinct without bees, and there would be major economic implications, we do have some resilience and we would likely find other methods to make these crops work; either through restoring bees and solving colony collapse, or by modifying plants. I want to point out a few issues with this point of view ( a very convenient, fear based, and impractically closed view) commonly shared amongst the general media outlets throughout North America, which in my opinion, stifles practical action and movement in the evolution of our beehive management and farming practices. 
- Honey bees are non-native to North America. The immigrated with the european colonists

- Honey bees are the cause for large scale mono crop production in the agricultural revolution because of a few facts:
      ---They can seek out and pollinate plants up to 5km away from their beehive
      --- Honey bees are VERY efficient pollinators in the fact that they, as a eusocial organism, seek out specific plants as a colony that offer the BEST source of nectar and pollen in their ecosystem and systematically maximize their yield from it
      - Honey bees are incredibly adaptable, even to a genetic level
(http://www.nature.com/news/job-swapping-makes-its-mark-on-honeybee-dna-1.11418) - Native bees make up over 1 million in diverse species found throughout North America (http://www.xerces.org/pollinator-conservation/native-bees/) 

- Many native bees offer pollination service within a small range (within 100m of their nest) and because they lay only up to a max of 300 individuals (bumble bees) and 20 individuals (solitary bees) within each females lifespan, there is less dependancy on BULK pollen and nectar, and therefore, these bee species are more resilient to variability in weather and climate over time.

- Other invertebrates and organisms offer pollination: beetles, flies, moths, butterflies, wasps, birds, bats, etc (http://www.xerces.org) 

- Solitary bees are actually responsible for most alfalfa pollination (http://www.pollinator.ca/canpolin/alfalfa_lcb.html) 

So, what does this ACTUALLY mean for our future if honey bee populations dwindle to the point of no return? It means that the current commercial food production model of mono cropping will fail. This means no more bulk purchasing of imported items at a subsidized rate, eating out of season, nor supply and demand principals (this is an issue with water anyways and drought is likely to cause our cheap rate for tomatoes in February to discontinue)

So, what CAN we expect? less mono crop, more diversity! And the American government knows this too and is actually doing something about it: 
http://www.xerces.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/04/using-farmbill-programs-for-pollinator-conservation.pdf

But, instead of promoting ACTIONABLE items to the world, it is media like this that continues to exacerbate the issue, making people feel helpless, encouraging even more rhetoric on how we are screwed by big-pharma when really, it is ALL OF US WHO CAN ACT by growing your own garden, creating habitat for native bees, learning to ID these bees and support them by creating hedgerows and micro-environemnts of gardens, trees and green spaces to support them. 

I am a beekeeper, I teach beekeeping for a living and to be honest, it is awesome. The fear of losing bees has encouraged more engagement and observation and consideration for our urban ecosystems then I thought possible in the past 6 years. But it is a continuation of this unimaginative, dated, and depressing rhetoric that keeps movements from gaining capacity as it leaves all those moving toward supporting ALL bees in a head space of eminent failure. We need to have progressive, positive, realistic and focussed approaches to this issue, and FEAR IS NOT AN OPTION.

Eliese, Apiaries and Bees for Communities

We. Have wild honey bees in our back yard that have been doing pretty well for themselves. As it is, we like having them, as they don't pose an active threat to us, the kids, or animals in the area. We have flowering plants in the yard almost year round, and depending on how cold the winter, even then too. We don't harvest from them for a few reasons. First is, we don't need to. Second is that they should be better able to come back after a big die off. If most of the adult bees die, the next generation should be able to grow up with plenty of stockpiled supplies, namely honey. The third would be location. They've set up shop in the peak of of my grandfather's wood working and tool shop, which is quite large and tall, and less prone to damage than the nearby trees.

We like having them there. Every few years or so, half the nest splits off and flies away to form, what I'm guessing and hoping, a new nest somewhere else. This is really cool to watch, though terrifying at the same time. You can actually walk right into the midst of the moving hive and if you're able to remain calm, none of them will sting you. Don't go poking sticks into the beard of the swarm, as this is where the new queen is hiding. The old nest even tolerates new moving nests that are passing through, not attacking them or running them off as you might think. I find they like to stay decently high up when they are moving, even when the 'beard' is resting on a tree branch.

If i happen to observe the nest doing this again, I will try to record it with video to show everyone.

Our nest is also very tolerant of human activity, you could walk under the nest beating cymbals and they would completely ignore you. I'm guessing it's because my grandfather's wood working tools are very loud, and they've gotten used to us walking under them all the time. The only times anyone has gotten stung by the bees from our nest would be if they stepped on one bare footed or swatted at it unknowingly. Most stinging insects will ignore you if you don't move.

I'm a third generation beekeeper and I remember the day my dad came home from a routine check on the bees a few summers ago and he was very scared because he found the bees in front of their hive staggering like they were drunk and had forgotten how to fly. Ordinarily if you pick a honeybee up with your hand she will try to sting you, but these bees would just stagger off the end of your hand and fall on the ground. He called every beekeeper he knew and sent some samples to the bee research lab at the University of Guelph, but no one had seen anything like it. We're pretty sure it was the neighbour who started using coated corn seed that summer, but other than the elevated levels of neonics tested in our ground water, we can't prove it was them... yet.
